children.html: This is You Love To See It — a weekly feature reviewing good news, progress and action steps that’s one of the many features available only to Lever supporting subscribers. Thank you so much for being a supporting subscriber — we couldn’t do this reporting without your support.

children.text: Good things are happening! Few people have managed to use right-wing blowhard Tucker Carlson’s massive audience for good, but the president of the Amazon Labor Union just showed everyone how it’s done — and along the way made the case for organizing workers. Also, a new study shows that global warming can be greatly reduced by holding governments to their existing promises. And a lawmaker is calling for the United States to give up its exemption from being held accountable for war crimes.
All this and much more in this week’s edition of You Love To See It, exclusively for supporting subscribers below.
National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) General Counsel Jennifer Abruzzo — a former colleague of
writer Matthew Cunningham-Cook at the Communications Workers of America — is taking aggressive action to enforce federal labor law. Her latest broadside is to
the “Joy Silk” doctrine, whereby the NLRB mandates immediate recognition and bargaining with a union when a majority of workers sign authorization cards.

The problem that Abruzzo & co. are working to solve is the sheer level of delays that employers put up against workers seeking to organize. Depending on the circumstances, it can take months to administer an election — needlessly delaying bargaining on a contract, which in and of itself can take a
The U.S. Chamber of Commerce responded to Abruzzo’s move with a

, saying: “We will oppose this action with every tool at our disposal, including litigation if needed.” Indeed, with the current composition of the courts, it seems likely that Abruzzo’s push will be overturned on appeal. But as
reporter Jesse Eisinger detailed in his excellent tome

, a key problem that both prosecutors and regulators have is a fear of losing cases, even if the facts on the ground warrant action. Good on Abruzzo for being willing to take a principled stand for workers’ rights, even if it means eventually taking a loss.
Chris Smalls Spreads The Union Message On Tucker Carlson
Amazon Labor Union President Chris Smalls on his show Thursday night. Predictably, an

nonprofit Media Matters for America decried Smalls’ appearance alongside the conservative commentator without posting an actual clip of the appearance. Smalls stayed on message about the importance of organizing unions at Amazon — and reached the thousands of Amazon workers nationwide who watch Carlson’s show.
Good News On A Bad Podcast
This week, Jen Psaki — President Joe Biden’s press secretary — announced on the Obama flack alumni project
that canceling student debt is “still on the table” and that the Biden administration will either cancel some amount of debt or extend the loan payment pause before the current one ends in August.

to deliver an update to millions of struggling debtors, the Debt Collective, the nation’s first debtors’ union, points out that it is still a major shift in what the administration has been saying on the issue and is good news for debtors.

children.text: Holding Politicians To Existing Promises Would Massively Limit Global Warming
that even if countries meet their existing carbon emission reduction pledges, the world is on track to overshoot 1.5 degrees Celsius of warming.
However, a new study shows that existing climate pledges could still significantly limit warming. The study,
that if countries keep the promises they made to reduce carbon emissions at last fall’s COP26 global climate talks, there is a good chance that warming can be limited to less than 2 degrees Celsius.
Every fraction of a degree of warming matters, and while a 2 degree-warmer world will bring

, extreme weather, food shortages, species extinction, and extreme heat than a 1.5 degree-warmer world, the new study shows that the COP26 pledges have paved the path to limit warming — if only countries stick to them.
The study authors warn that countries are
meeting those pledges, and many countries are moving in the wrong direction.
